content.notes: Content not refactored in Phase 1; original preserved under payload.

payload.posterTitle: Oceania: Reefs, Rainforests, and Island Worlds

biomes.name: Kakadu Wetlands
biomes.description: Kakadu’s wetlands flood in the wet season and shrink in the dry. Billabongs fill with lilies and birds, while saltwater crocodiles patrol warm waters across a landscape rich in Aboriginal culture.

biomes.name: Ningaloo Reef
biomes.description: Ningaloo Reef lies close to shore with clear water and vibrant coral. Snorkelers can meet turtles, manta rays, and whale sharks, where reef life thrives beside Australia’s dry coast.

biomes.name: Southern Alps of New Zealand
biomes.description: New Zealand’s Southern Alps are jagged mountains carved by glaciers. Snowfields, turquoise lakes, and fast rivers fill the valleys, creating dramatic scenery and tough alpine habitat.

biomes.name: New Caledonia Barrier Reef
biomes.description: New Caledonia’s barrier reef rings a huge turquoise lagoon. Coral, seagrass, and mangroves support turtles, sharks, and reef fish in one of the planet’s largest reef systems.

biomes.name: Shark Bay
biomes.description: Shark Bay is a World Heritage coast of seagrass beds, clear shallows, and ancient stromatolites. Dolphins and dugongs thrive here, where warm water and protected bays shelter marine life.

biomes.name: Fraser Island (K’gari)
biomes.description: K’gari is the world’s largest sand island, with dunes, rainforests, and clear freshwater lakes. Ocean waves, shifting sand, and wild dingoes make this island feel both fragile and fierce.

biomes.name: Hawaiian Islands
biomes.description: Hawaiʻi rises from volcanoes in the Pacific. Lava built the islands, and rain grew forests. Coral reefs ring many shores, while unique plants and birds evolved far from any continent.
